Fancy US burger chains are becoming tasty business the UK, partly by charging British customers twice as much as their American counterparts for the same burgers.

Smashburger, a Colorado-based chain that promises to make burgers to order and never use frozen meat, is preparing to become the latest in a string of artisan US burger joints, including Shake Shack and Five Guys, to open UK outposts.

The chain, which has grown to 315 sites just eight years since its foundation by serial food entrepreneur Tom Ryan, is now scouting for UK sites and hopes to open up to 35 across Britain.

Twitter

Pinterest

 Smashburger in New York. Photograph: Alamy

“The United Kingdom is hungry for better burgers and presents a significant opportunity for us to meet the global demand in the category,” Smashburger’s chief executive Scott Crane said.

The company has partnered with MSG Group, which owns 120 Domino’s Pizza restaurants in the UK, to lead the expansion. Smashburger UK will be led by Tim Lowther, MSG’s managing director, who also introduced Shake Shack and Five Guys to the UK.

“The fast casual dining market has yet to reach its potential in the United Kingdom and there is a huge opportunity for brands such as Smashburger,” Lowther said. “Due to its focus on quality and taste, we are certain Smashburger will be a success and more importantly satisfy the burger appetite for the next 30 years and beyond.”

Five Guys, which is named after its founder Jerry and Janie Murrell and their sons Matt, Jim, Chad and Ben, opened its first UK store in London’s Covent Gardenin July 2013 in partnership with Carphone Warehouse billionaire Charles Dunstone.

Facebook

Twitter

Pinterest

 Barack Obama orders a hamburger at Five Guys in Washington, 2009. Photograph: Gerald Herbert/AP

The next day fellow US burger joint Shake Shack, which recently floated on the New York stock exchange and has a market value of $2.5bn, opened its doors just a few yards away on the same street.

While Shake Shack has stuck with just the one venue, Five Guys has now expanded to about 25 across the country.

Both chains are charging more than they do in the US for the same burgers.

A Shack burger in Manhattan costs $5.19 (£3.40). In Covent Garden it is £5.25 ($8.05). A standard Five Guys burger in New York costs $6.25 (£4.07), on Long Acre in Covent Garden it costs £6.75 ($10.40).
